abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey a satisfactory project
            outcome, though sustainability is unlikely, and
            institutional development impacts are only modest. Among the
            lessons learned, it is reinforced that strong country
            ownership is essential to support reforms. As it so
            happened, the political environment in the country was
            fragile, and increasingly uncertain, which hampered reforms,
            and eroded new concepts, originally established for primary
            health care. In fact, the absence of a health sector policy
            (though widely discussed, debated, and accepted at the
            republican, and oblast (local) levels early on), had adverse
            effects on the development of family medicine care. The
            nature of health sector reforms, as supported by this
            project, is inherently political, and its success depends on
            the careful integration of the political dimensions of
            reform with health technical aspects. Thus, identification
            of project risks, based on assessment of the political
            environment for reform - through a political mapping
            exercise and social assessment - is needed, and the Bank
            should identify risks, and focus on a proactive risk
            management approach, leveraging the Bank's resources.
            Additionally, an important element for project success, is
            to maintain close coordination with donors.

5083490.trustfund:
TF036722-KAZAKHSTAN - HEALTH PROJECT,TF036721-KAZAKHSTAN - HEALTH PROJECT,TF035724-KAZAKSTAN - HEALTH PROJECT,TF034558-KAZAKSTAN - LIVING
            STANDARDS(PILOTING ALTERNATIVE CHILD CARE),TF035373-KAZAKSTAN - HEALTH PROJECT,TF038774-ARMENIA - SUPERVISION OF
            PRIMARY HEALTH CARE PROJECTS

abstracts.cdata!:
The Health Project seeks to achieve a
            sustainable health system through improved efficiency of the
            health care system at the national level, and implement an
            integrated health reform, strengthening primary health care,
            and improving the financial and management capacity at
            service delivery in East Kazakhstan and Almaty oblasts. The
            project includes components at the national and regional
            levels as follows: 1) At the national level: a) Tuberculosis
            (TB) control is a priority within the State Program Health.
            The component will provide, together with the World Health
            Organization (WHO) and the United States Agency for
            International Development (USAID), financing for the
            diagnosis and treatment of TB. b) Substantial modernization
            in health promotion is needed, thus technical assistance
            will be provided by WHO in areas such as, professional
            development and health promotion action plans. c) The health
            care system capacity will be strengthened, and clinical
            training centers will be established. 2) At the regional
            level: a) The improvement of primary health care services
            will take effect in two districts, to develop nationally as
            the program progresses. b) The two participating districts
            will initiate health financing reforms, and, management
            information systems will be developed. c) The facilities
            rationalization and rehabilitation component will promote
            merging urban and smaller facilities to improve health care quality.
